meta_data.title: Adaptive Multi-Interest Debiasing Framework for Cross-Domain Sequential Recommendation Under Open-World Assumptions
affiliations: Department of Computer Science, University of Nowhere
Institute of Data Science, University of Everywhere
meta_data.abstract: This study introduces a new framework, AMID, designed to address the open-world challenges in cross-domain sequential recommendation (CDSR). By leveraging adaptive multi-interest modeling and debiasing techniques, AMID effectively mitigates selection bias and utilizes non-overlapping users. Comprehensive experiments demonstrate its superiority over existing CDSR methods.

relate work.related papers:
- Hu et al. 2018. "Conet: A Collaborative Neural Network for Ranking Cross-domain Recommendations"
- Ma et al. 2019. "Pi-Net: A Parallel Information Transfer Network for Shared-Account Cross-Domain Sequential Recommendation"
- Sheng et al. 2021. "STAR: A Next Generation Cross-Domain Recommendation Framework"
- Ricci et al. 2009. "Recommender Systems Handbook: A Comprehensive Guide"
relate work.comparisons with related methods: AMID is distinct from traditional CDSR methods as it focuses on non-overlapping users and traverses open-world domains, offering solutions for selection biases not addressed by conventional models.

high_level_summary.summary of this paper: This paper presents an innovative framework termed AMID that targets the limitations of existing cross-domain sequential recommendation methods under open-world settings. It achieves this by incorporating adaptive multi-interest modeling and a doubly robust estimator to address selection bias and enhance prediction accuracy.
high_level_summary.research purpose: To overcome the limitations of traditional CDSR models by constructing a framework capable of handling non-overlapping users and reducing biases inherent in open-world scenarios.
high_level_summary.research challenge: Only partial solutions exist for non-overlapping user data and selection bias in traditional CDSR settings, necessitating a novel framework like AMID.
high_level_summary.method summary: AMID employs a foundational framework that uses a multi-interest information module (MIM) and a doubly robust estimator (DRE) to model sequences accurately, mitigating bias and enhancing predictive performance.
high_level_summary.conclusion: The AMID framework effectively addresses major challenges in cross-domain sequential recommendation scenarios, establishing a new benchmark for future applications.

Method.description: AMID employs adaptive multi-interest and debiasing strategies to handle open-world cross-domain sequential recommendation challenges.
Method.problem formultaion: Modeling sequences for partially overlapping environments with selection bias correction.
Method.model: AMID integrates single-domain sequential recommendation systems with a multi-interest information module and doubly robust estimator.
Method.theoretical analysis: The paper presents a theoretical evaluation demonstrating the superior bias and convergence properties of the AMID estimator.
Method.complexity: The paper identifies the effort required for group construction with a complexity of O(ZÂ²), suggesting future efficiency improvements.
Method.algorithm step: The algorithm consists of interest group formation, cross-domain propagation, and a prediction layer executed in training phases with empirical evaluations.

Experiments.setup: Experiments were conducted using Amazon and MYbank datasets for cross-dataset validation in platforms with varying user overlaps.
Experiments.hyperparameters: Common hyperparameters such as embedding dimensions of 128, batch sizes of 512, learning rates of 0.001 were uniformly applied.
Experiments.results: AMID outperformed existing methods with improvements: 26.48% (in NDCG) on Cloth domain and 5.60% in Fund domain scenarios, establishing its superiority in various tasks.
Experiments.performance: The AMID framework demonstrated significant performance enhancements across all tested domains, particularly with high non-overlapping user ratios.
Experiments.analysis: AMID's methods reveal high effectiveness in attenuating selection bias and consolidating cross-domain preferences.
Experiments.ablation study: An ablation study confirmed the effectiveness of key components like MIM, showing even without DRE, substantial performance was yielded.

conclusion.summary: This paper presents AMID, an adaptive multi-interest debiasing framework that effectively handles cross-domain sequential recommendation challenges in open-world settings.
conclusion.future work: Future work will explore more efficient group construction methods to address increasing domain numbers and enhance AMID's scalability.
